results.title: Judy Grinham
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “British Sporting Personalities”.
The swimming career of Judy Grinham turned on her decision, when only twelve years of age, to concentrate on her backstroke, and on her partnership with the great swimming coach, Reg Laxton. Shows her racing performance in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and the 1958 Commonwealth Games and a glimpse of her private life as well.

results.title: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) puppeteer costume and double's duplicate
results.credit_line:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions
results.brief_description: When costume designer Edie Kurzer was crafting the jacket Judy (Mia Wasikowska) wears while performing in puppet shows, she had to create not only something bold that would set the star apart, but also something that would fit the character Polly (Lucy Velik).

constellations_primary.name: Like a puppet on a string
constellations_primary.description: From the silly to the sinister, puppets, muppets, dummies and toys on-screen.

results.title_for_label: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) puppeteer costume and double’s duplicate
results.description: When costume designer Edie Kurzer was crafting the jacket Judy (Mia Wasikowska) wears while performing in puppet shows, she had to create not only something bold that would set the star apart, but also something that would fit the character Polly (Lucy Velik). This meant Kurzer needed to design a piece that would fit two different builds. A double of the jacket with just the sleeves was also made for stand-in puppeteers, who were filmed during close-ups of the characters’ hands. Having a second costume for stand-ins saves time while shooting so that the main actor doesn’t need to stop working to give a double their costume.
description_for_label: When costume designer Edie Kurzer was crafting the jacket Judy (Mia Wasikowska) wears while performing in puppet shows, she had to create not only something bold that would set the star apart, but also something that would fit the character Polly (Lucy Velik). This meant Kurzer needed to design a piece that would fit two different builds. A double of the jacket with just the sleeves was also made for stand-in puppeteers, who were filmed during close-ups of the characters’ hands. Having a second costume for stand-ins saves time while shooting so that the main actor doesn’t need to stop working to give a double their costume.

A double of the jacket with just the sleeves was also made for stand-in puppeteers, who were filmed during close-ups of the characters’ hands. Having a second costume for stand-ins saves time while shooting so that the main actor doesn’t need to stop working to give a double their costume.

results.title: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) costume
results.credit_line:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions
results.material_description: new and re-purposed materials, cotton, linen, silk, leather, rubber, metal
results.brief_description: Judy’s everyday outfit is a tapestry of petticoat, skirt, apron, blouse and bodice. This layered approach that costume designer Edie Kurzer took allows different parts of the costume to be added or removed to create different looks, while reflecting the character’s downtrodden background.

constellations_primary.name: Women, crime and literature
constellations_primary.description: Judy & Punch draws on a classic puppet show that's been reframed by director Mirrah Foulkes as a feminist tale, much like the works that put women at the centre in this Constellation.

results.description: Poverty is rife in the world of Mirrah Foulkes’ Judy & Punch (2019). While Judy and Punch make a living performing marionette shows and have both everyday clothes and puppeteering outfits, most characters in the film, set in the 16th century, can only afford one set of threads. Judy’s everyday outfit is a tapestry of petticoat, skirt, apron, blouse and bodice. This layered approach that costume designer Edie Kurzer took allows different parts of the costume to be added or removed to create different looks, while reflecting the character’s downtrodden background.
description_for_label: Poverty is rife in the world of Mirrah Foulkes’ Judy & Punch (2019). While Judy and Punch make a living performing marionette shows and have both everyday clothes and puppeteering outfits, most characters in the film, set in the 16th century, can only afford one set of threads. Judy’s everyday outfit is a tapestry of petticoat, skirt, apron, blouse and bodice. This layered approach that costume designer Edie Kurzer took allows different parts of the costume to be added or removed to create different looks, while reflecting the character’s downtrodden background.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions

results.title: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) bloodied costume
results.credit_line:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions
results.material_description: new and repurposed materials, cotton, linen, silk, leather, rubber, metal, coloured dye
results.brief_description: Costume designer Edie Kurzer applied the fake blood on this costume while the actor wore it so that it covered the fabric realistically and looked authentic.

constellations_primary.name: Blood, shot
constellations_primary.description: The fake blood used by costume designer Edie Kurzer in Judy & Punch is connected to a long, bloody lineage in cinema.

results.description: Lying on the floor is a bloodied double of Judy’s outfit. Costume designers don’t apply blood to the main version of the costume in case it needs to be used later. While the skirt on the left is made from a rare curtain from the period, this one is made from corduroy because it is seen less in the film. Fabrics aren’t the only important thing: the colour of the blood is too, and it needs to be tested to make sure it looks real on film. It’s also applied to the costume while the actor wears it, because it falls differently whether they’re standing or sitting.
description_for_label: Lying on the floor is a bloodied double of Judy’s outfit. Costume designers don’t apply blood to the main version of the costume in case it needs to be used later. While the skirt on the left is made from a rare curtain from the period, this one is made from corduroy because it is seen less in the film. Fabrics aren’t the only important thing: the colour of the blood is too, and it needs to be tested to make sure it looks real on film. It’s also applied to the costume while the actor wears it, because it falls differently whether they’re standing or sitting.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions

results.title: Judy & Punch reference images from Edie Kurzer's studio
results.brief_description: Edie Kurzer often explores mood and atmosphere with images instead of using them as direct influences. While she may use sketches to work through details, she gains more inspiration from objects like feathers, buttons or fabrics.
results.title_for_label: Judy & Punch reference images from Edie Kurzer’s studio
